Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Large Scale Stochastic Control: A Math Programming and Discrete Optimization Lens

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project seeks to deliver new, approximate approaches for large-scale stochastic control that are easy to implement `out of the box' with little or no expert tuning. At a high level, the research will leverage algorithmic techniques and modes of analysis developed for deterministic optimization problems, in the design of algorithms for large-scale stochastic control. The project consists of two complementary thrusts. The first concerns deriving new math programming formulations for Approximate Dynamic Programming (ADP) via non-standard characterizations of optimal control. ADP algorithms constitute a general approach to large-scale control. These new math programming formulations promise simplicity and robustness, while potentially admitting strong theoretical performance guarantees. The second thrust concerns identifying classes of stochastic control problems wherein one may combat uncertainty with frequent re-optimization and limited `lookahead'. One avenue will consist of developing an abstract modeling framework for a large class of stochastic control problems analogous to that for discrete optimization problems over matroids - an eminently well-studied and relatively tractable class of discrete optimization problems. A second avenue will consist of analyzing dynamic `allocation' or `packing' problems whose deterministic analogues are simple linear programs; such models arise in settings as diverse as revenue management, healthcare and queueing. The goal is to pursue the analysis and development of extremely simple, easy to implement, re-optimization based schemes. The tool facilitating this analysis will consist of a characterization of the dynamics of `basis changes' in such problems.

The research agenda above is rooted in real world applications. ADP algorithms have proven to be valuable tools in areas as far ranging as oil exploration to option pricing; the agenda above will potentially bring these schemes closer to being `technologies'. The matroid-like framework mentioned captures features of non-standard processing systems that arise ubiquitously in critical healthcare delivery settings among other applications. The dynamic allocation problems we focus on form the core computational routine in decisions made in online advertising systems, revenue management system and even internet switches, frequently at sub milli-second timescales. As such, the algorithms developed as part of this research will potentially be deployed in several manufacturing, healthcare and e-commerce related settings. In summary, if successful, this research will provide fundamental and practically relevant new tools for stochastic control at both the `generic' and `highly suctured' ends of the problem spectrum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Some of the greatest data-driven challenges today, ranging from self-driving cars to personalized medicine, are examples of Large-scale Dynamic Optimization problems. Effective algorithms for such problem thus have the potential of simultaneously moving forward the state of the art across multiple application domains. This proposal sought to leverage algorithms developed for deterministic optimization problems in the design of algorithms for large-scale stochastic control problems. We also sought to demonstrate the power of these new approaches across multiple application areas. In fact, the research conducted as part of this proposal has led to several powerful new algorithmic approaches for dynamic optimization. As part of the research, these new approaches have been applied to a variety of application areas, ranging from cloud computing to data-driven patient flow optimization. The research has been broadly recognized by multiple prestigious awards; these awards have recognized both theoretical as well as practical contributions.

Research conducted as part of this proposal has made important contributions to the area of Approximate Dynamic Programming (ADP). Specifically, we have developed several new approaches to ADP that leverage, as their core computational workhorse, algorithms for convex programming. Algorithms for the latter are mature enough to be considered technologies, so that we have sought to bring a similar level of algorithmic robustness to ADP. Two algorithmic approaches that were pioneered as part of this research include the so-called Smoothed Approximate Linear Program and the Path-wise Optimization Approach. Both of these approaches have been recognized by significant awards. More importantly, the ideas pioneered by these approaches have formed the basis of a great deal of follow on work by the broader research community and the basis of practical applications at commercial ventures. We have also made significant progress on more traditional domains within dynamic optimization, including the areas of model predictive control and bandit algorithms. The work on model predictive control, for example, has fueled a new paradigm for algorithm design in digital advertising and the industrial impact of the research on dynamic assortment optimization was recognized by a premier practice prize.

Finally, it is worth noting that research programs that grew out of this proposal have matured into exciting projects in their own right. This includes work on the design of resource allocation problems for cloud computing, as well as the optimal design of A-B tests. A number of students at MIT participated in the research funded by this award. Several have gone on to make significant contributions within academia (and are now Professors themselves), as well as industry, where they have pioneered commercial applications inspired by their research funded by this grant.
